comment: Took her over the summer, no complaints. 20% discussions(5, min 550 words including replies), 20% quizzes, 20% case study (essay), 20% video analysis (essay) and 20% final. Quizzes and final have a fair bit of writing involved. Separates each online lecture into parts (4-5) which I hate. Overall you won't regret taking her but be prepared to write.
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Class was simple enough, with only five graded assignments including the final exam. She is a rather strict grader with very little feedback, and you don't see your grades until the end of the course so your grade is kind of up in the air until the end. I found her video lectures to be hard to follow and outdated.

Professor McCalla is genuinely just a really kind teacher. She is there to impart knowledge and wants you as the student to succeed. She is obviously more worried about your understanding of the material than a grade. She may not be tech savvy. but she is super flexible and relaxed about assignments.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Participation matters--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. McCalla was great! I said participation was mandatory because some days she did exit tickets for a grade. There were not many assignments for the class though so it was kind of stressful if you got a lower grade on one of them. But she is very understanding of her students and clearly communicates her expectations for the assignments given.

The class was easier than an in-person class. Have 5 grades total in the grade book. Discussion Posts every week (combined into one grade at the end), 2 video analyses, 1 quiz, and a final exam. She is a tough-grader without a doubt, but communicates what she wants.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Clear grading criteria--Graded by few things

comment: Class only has a few grades and she grades them incredibly difficult. Lectures are really long and they can be pretty boring. when you take the final please triple-check your answers because I was really confident in what I submitted and did not expect the grade I got.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Get ready to read--Lecture heavy

comment: Dr. McCalla understands the material extensively with interesting lectures, however they are outdated and she is an incredibly tough grader for a prereq class. She would often provide vague feedback and there are few grades, so it is up in the air as to what your grade will be until the end of the course. I would take someone else...

In class participation counts for 20%, and the other grades are 2 video analysis papers, a quiz, and a final. Her assignment instructions arent clear; she told us to write in APA but docked points if our citations weren't in MLA, and will assign a 500 word maximum when she means minimum but takes points off and it's our fault if we write >500 words
rating_tags: Participation matters--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. McCalla does not offer feedback on your midterms or analysis assignments. She will not grade your weekly discussion posts until the end of the semester. You will be unsure of your progress until it's too late to withdraw. Her lectures are actually quite interesting and short, but her few assignments and poor grading scheme spoil it.

I took her for the summer. I did not enjoy her class, primarily because she did not post her PowerPoints separately from her lectures, and it was very hard to understand through her accent. Other than that, there were five discussion posts, all graded at the end of the term, one quiz and a final exam. The final was easy, there is a lot of writing!
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: Dr. McCalla's class was by far one of the best, most enlightening courses I have taken. I would definitely take this class again. She is very organized and you will know what to expect. Do all of your assignments and its not hard to get an A. She is a tough grader but she will tell you what she is looking for. Don't hesitate to take her class.

She posted lecture videos on D2L. All of our assignments and discussions were very organized. It's clear what she expects of each assignment and she gives good feedback, but she was a tough grader IMO. Textbook is mandatory whether you get it online or physically. I enjoyed taking this class!

Professor McCalla was great! Her lectures were always prepared well for class and she never missed class. Attendance was mandatory but in-class discussions were very fun. Not many assignments, 5 including the final so do well and also make sure to be in class because participation is a grade and she gives out enough extra credit. Lots of writing !
There were like 5 grades in this class. Worried me about failing, but ended with an A! Dr McCalla was super sweet and emailed back very fast. I would take her again
rating_tags: Tough grader--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: She was very kind and a good professor. Weekly discussion post +2 replies with a few essays and quizzes. Major assignments are graded promptly, but discussion post grades aren't released until the end of the semester. Gives good feedback on how to improve on the major writings. If you like to procrastinate, tread lightly. Otherwise, easy class.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Gives good feedback--Graded by few things

comment: Did not communicate with professor at all throughout the course. Pretty self-explanatory class. However, she did not grade the discussions until the end of the semester. Besides that, it was an okay course.

Professor McCalla is sweet, and you can really tell she has a passion for philosophy, however, I would not recommend this class. It is very discussion post based, and she only gives out one quiz that then accounted for 20% of our grade alone. She is a very tough grader and does not input your discussion post grades until the end of the semester.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She's a very kind teacher and clearly has a passion for philosophy. I do have to say though; she has very little assignments and provides little to no feedback. Her class is very discussion heavy and she is a strict grader. The textbook is not needed, and exams are all open notes. I would not recommend this class.
rating_tags: Tough grader--Lecture heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She is a sweet woman who cares about her students. She has a slightly confusing teaching style but the content is easy to understand. Attendance is kinda mandatory, meaning you are randomly thrown a graded assignment in-class, usually on fridays. If you try at least a little bit in this class, you should get an A.

This was an easy A. Very few assignments. Although attendance is mandatory, the class is more like an open ended discussion when we all just talk a lot about philosophy. No papers. Few quizzes, 3 test, which are all online. I definitely recommend taking this class, because of the light load.

Attendance isn't mandatory and the lectures are easy to understand, however the class had few assignments to be graded and the "mid-semester quiz" and final are required to be wordy and long. The word count for the final and quiz were ridiculous and hard to achieve.
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Test heavy--Graded by few things

comment: She is a great professor! Fun lectures (still fun even if you don't like philosophy). She's understanding and although the test are heavy (lots of writing) they are simple. Don't have to show up 100% and still can make a good grade (ignore mine i slacked off a little). :)
rating_tags: Get ready to read--EXTRA CREDIT--Gives good feedback

comment: She was very merciful when I took her. Attendance isn't mandatory. Discussions don't require replies. 200 words max. Her exams are very dense, but easy because they're online, open-note with no lockdown browser, you get 10 whole hours to do it, and they're about 15 questions including essay questions. You don't need to buy the book.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Caring--Graded by few things

comment: Philosophy is already a challenging class but she makes it even harder. Gives journal assignments then doesn't grade them until the end of the course, no feedback. One midterm quiz and final exam both had multiple very lengthy answer requirements. I was always lost in class but discussions and the book helped.

This professor and class are heavy in discussion. This is not a bad thing and helps understand the course material. There are many opportunities for grades and this makes missed or failed assignments not so detrimental. This class was actually fun, and the professor cares about the subject deeply. Definitely a highlight of my semester.
I highly recommend this class. Not too difficult and super interesting.

Dr McCalla is a great prof. Only downside is that we only have 1 quiz, 1 video analysis and a final that looks just like the quiz. Those 3 grades are 82 percent of your grade. The other 18 are weekly journal entries that when she finally graded... didn't even look at them. So going to class and taking notes ended up being a total waste of time.

Dr. McCalla is an amazing philosophy professor! Her lectures are amazing, in-depth, and easy to follow. She also approaches every topic objectively without any bias and lets every student voice their opinion without any fear of pushback. Only graded assignments are weekly journal entries and a handful of quizzes.
